text: The 2008 V8 Supercar Championship Series was the twelfth V8 Supercar Championship Series and the twelfth series in which V8 Supercars contested the premier Australian touring car title. The championship began on 21 February at the Clipsal 500 on the streets of Adelaide and concluded on 7 December at Oran Park Raceway. It consisted of 14 rounds covering all states and the Northern Territory of Australia as well as rounds in New Zealand and Bahrain.Race start at Round 2, Eastern Creek Jamie Whincup secured the Drivers championship with two races in hand with victory in race 1 of the 2008 NRMA Motoring & Services Grand Finale. Whincup was also awarded the 49th Australian Touring Car Championship title by CAMS.Australian Titles Retrieved from www.camsmanual.com.au on 20 May 2009. 20 May 2009. 1000 only ==Rule Changes== The points system was changed for 2008. Points were awarded to the top 30 drivers, with 300 points being the most available to a driver in each round.V8 Supercars to reward more teams in 2008 points score Official Site of the Australian V8 Supercar Championship Series retrieved on 25 January 2008 In Friday practice sessions, drivers who had finished in the top 15 in the 2007 Championship were not permitted to participate for the first 30 minutes.Ottley, S. "Champs penalised" Herald Sun 23 January 2008 ==Technical changes== An option to use sequential gearboxes in lieu of H-pattern gearboxes was introduced.V8s get into sequence Motorsport News issue 10 26 June 2007 page 7 Initially optional, sequential gearboxes later became mandatory. ==Driver changes== Russell Ingall signed with Paul Morris Motorsport and raced under the identity of Supercheap Auto Racing. In a complicated series of moves several drivers have been shuffled around the Holden teams. The juggling began with Todd Kelly signing with Perkins Engineering. Reigning series champion Garth Tander took the #1 plate to the Holden Racing Team with Toll sponsorship and some key personnel led by Rob Crawford transfer across teams with him. And finally, former Supercheap Auto driver Paul Dumbrell took Tander's seat at the HSV Dealer Team. Second tier Fujitsu series champion team Tony D'Alberto Racing moved to the V8 Supercar series, and took over the running of the Rod Nash Racing owned franchise, replacing Independent Racing Cars who previously operated the team. Tony D'Alberto replaced Steve Owen as driver.A full field motorsport enews retrieved on 29 January 2008 Paul Cruickshank Racing signed Fabian Coulthard to replace the retired John Bowe.Old faces, new seats motorsport enews retrieved on 18 December 2007 Marcus Marshall drove the Irwin backed Falcon at Britek Motorsport. Dean Canto announced on his website that he had his contract with Garry Rogers Motorsport terminated a year early. He later drove for Ford Performance Racing in the endurance events.Statement regarding Dean Canto and the 2008 series Dean Canto Racing retrieved on 12 January 2008 Garry Rogers Motorsport announced their new driver as Fujitsu series runner up, and WPS Racing enduro driver, Michael Caruso.Michael Caruso joins Garry Rogers Motorsport Official Site of the Australian V8 Supercar Championship Series retrieved on 14 January 2008 Team Kiwi Racing purchased a former Triple Eight Race Engineering Falcon and ran the car themselves. While the team had not made a formal announcement, V8Supercars have published Fujitsu series front runner Kayne Scott as the team's driver.TKR goes it alone, Scott driving crash.net retrieved on 15 January 2008V8 Supercar Championship Series gets full 2008 grid Official Site of the Australian V8 Supercar Championship Series retrieved on 31 January 2008 Although due to a date clash with Round 2 and the final of the New Zealand V8 series, Scott was not available and was replaced by Chris Pither.Pither: Kiwi Sub motorsport enews retrieved on 4 March 2008 Reversing a previous decision to fold their team, Paul Weel Racing announced their return for the 2008 season and ran a single VE Commodore for Andrew Thompson.Andrew Thompson signs with PWR Racing Official Site of the Australian V8 Supercar Championship Series retrieved on 25 January 2008 Former PWR racer Cameron McConville signed with Brad Jones Racing, a team he raced for previously in the mid-90s when it ran the Audi touring car program. The team also changed manufacturer camps to become a Holden team and ran with the technical assistance of Walkinshaw Performance, the organisation that runs the Holden Racing Team and HSV Dealer Teams.New Cars, New Driver for Team BOC Team BOC website retrieved on 29 January 2008 Ford Rising Stars Racing named Formula 3 Euroseries racer Michael Patrizi as the driver for their début season. However the team wasn’t ready to start their season until the second round of the year at Eastern Creek Raceway at the earliest. The team utilised the second of the two Paul Weel Racing franchises.Chance and Challenge motorsport enews retrieved on 30 January 2008 Stone Brothers Racing named teenager Shane van Gisbergen to the #9 Ford Falcon, replacing Russell Ingall. Van Gisbergen was linked to SBR last season and was placed with Team Kiwi Racing in the second half of the season after TKR's previous partnership with Ford Performance Racing dissolved.Van Gisbergen claims prize SBR drive Stone Brothers Racing website retrieved on 30 January 2008 Despite previously announcing that they would be forced to sell their franchise from lack of a major sponsor and technical partner,Walden Motorsport Forced To Sell Or Lease Licence. Norrgard Motorsport Development retrieved on 21 December 2007 Walden Motorsport had committed to run and V8Supercar's website had named Australian Production Car Championship racer Garth Walden as the driver in the teams Ford Falcon, although it has yet to be confirmed that the team actually have possession of an eligible car. After failing to appear at the first two rounds the franchise has been placed for sale.Walden licence for sale Official Site of the Australian V8 Supercar Championship Series retrieved on 20 March 2008 WPS Racing announced the closure of the team with the vehicles and equipment sold off to new owners. The franchises have already been sold within TEGA.
